timeline.bodyText:
MISSING does not indicate the "easiest grade". The easiest / well maintained grade is grade1. Missing means that we don't know the grade and could assume some other grade, but I wouldn't assume that missing grades mean it's grade1.
Other is not really the worst grade either :).
timeline.author: boldtrn
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -21,8 +21,7 @@
 
 /**
  * This enum defines the track type of an edge which describes how well-maintained a certain track is.
- * If not tagged the value will be MISSING (the default and easiest grad) and all edges that do not fit get OTHER as

replies.bodyText: Maybe we should add some more information on this in the comment defining each grade? But probably it is enough the way it is in the OSM wiki.
replies.author: boldtrn

replies.bodyText: BTW: Other is refered as worst value in other comments as well. I would propose to change this for all occurrences. Other is just an undefined state IMHO.
replies.author: boldtrn

replies.bodyText:
Hmmh, I think what is meant here is that in some cases these enums could be also converted into the corresponding number and then an order is required. But probably this wasn't a good idea and with better scripting support we can now refer to potential bad track types via:
track_type.ordinal() > 3 || track_type == MISSING
instead of just:
track_type.ordinal() > 3

But probably it is enough the way it is in the OSM wiki.

As we do not have a 1:1 mapping I would not do this. Also we should make this more explicit and improve our documentation independent of OSM wiki.
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText: The MISSING type is related to how encoded values with no value are handled AFAIK.
replies.author: otbutz

replies.bodyText:
Hmmh, I think what is meant here is that in some cases these enums could be also converted into the corresponding number and then an order is required.

Ah, now I see how this was meant. Thanks for the explanation.

As we do not have a 1:1 mapping I would not do this. Also we should make this more explicit and improve our documentation independent of OSM wiki.

Don't we have a 1:1 mapping for tracktype? But sure I can add some more information on this, if you'd want this?
replies.author: boldtrn

replies.bodyText:
Do we really need a distinction between MISSING and OTHER ? We should probably treat them as the same thing and drop OTHER completely.
Should we reorder the constants according to the grade?

    MISSING("missing"), GRADE5("grade5"), GRADE4("grade4"),
    GRADE3("grade3"), GRADE2("grade2"),GRADE1("grade1");
replies.author: otbutz

replies.bodyText:
Re 1: yes, you are right
Re 2: interesting idea. But then gradeX != X ... tricky :D

Don't we have a 1:1 mapping for tracktype? But sure I can add some more information on this, if you'd want this?

Yes, for now this is probably identical. But in general our aim should be to have values that can be easily used in our CustomWeighting.
replies.author: karussell
karussell

replies.bodyText: Ok sure, should we apply the same to the other encoded values as well? Like Surface, RouteNetwork, etc.? We have other and missing there as well.
replies.author: boldtrn

replies.bodyText: No, for surface etc there are definitely many "other" tags that should not mean "missing". In case of tracktype no other values can occur according to wiki and not many occur in real world according to taginfo.
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText: And also for RouteNetwork there are plenty of tags in the wiki and real world that we cannot handle but should not mean MISSING.
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText: Hmmh, for route=foot or route=hiking or route=bicycle it seems there are only 4 possible values. But the RouteNetwork enum could be also used for other routes? ... not sure.
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText: Ah now I understand your reasoning for removing OTHER, thanks. Ok I updated the PR.
replies.author: boldtrn
